ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: I think it was supposed to be an in-person lecture, but since there were only 6 students in the class, it effectively became a seminar type of class.
A combination of lecture and discussion section
Twice weekly live virtual lectures and once weekly live virtual seminar
Live virtual lecture + live virtual discussion section
Some prerecorded lectures

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Knowledge: I learned a lot about music history, and general music narratives throughout the years. 

Skills: Looking at the bigger picture with regard to appreciating music, not just focusing on sonic details

insights into the history of music through conceptual and thematic lenses that made it novel for me, despite the fact that I have been reading and learning about music for years, especially in regards to questions of meaning and identity.
I learned about the history of music/genres, their contexts, the technical aspects that make up said songs/genres, and how to think analytically about the significance and purpose of said music
I learned the history and through-lines of (mostly Western) music touching on not only culture but also technology, economics, politics, gender, race, ethnicity.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: The class was very engaging, very interactive, and the environment was well-suited towards learning. The class environment is very welcoming, especially with regard to different degrees of music backgrounds and familiarity. The material was very interesting, and the workload was more than reasonable.

Weaknesses: Sometimes the narratives presented in the textbook were hard to follow. I don't think this is a problem with MUSI 175 specifically, but more likely has to do with the textbook itself. That said, I think it's pretty hard to deliver a history of music course that does not have confusing narratives here and there.

The only weakness I can possibly think of is that I wish we could cover even more content! Obviously that is not realistic, but the world of music is so vast and I would love to keep exploring it further in the ways in which we did in this class.
The course was excellent in facilitating interesting and engaging discussion coupled with great assignments. Sometimes there was some logistical ambiguity, but it was always remedied

I really appreciated the study guides Professor Davis put together for the quizzes and final exam - they were very helpful for reducing stress and improving understanding, especially when I was trying to connect things at the end of the course.
Very detailed feedback on assignments, really helpful study guides for the quizzes, easy and interesting readings.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: Despite music-based classes being subject to the zoom audio lag, I feel like the class didn't run into many problems.
Besides a few minor technical difficulties that were promptly addressed with a little troubleshooting and creativity, I'd say this class was very successful online.
The virtual format worked exceedingly well for this course

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Even if you are a musician, you still learn a lot about music history and appreciation by taking the course. Music is a very interesting topic, and we rarely have the opportunity to engage with music intellectually unless you major in it. However, any non-music majors would still find enjoyment in the class. The biweekly quizzes might be a deterrent, but honestly those were not too stressful.

In a heartbeat. I learned so much without any anxiety of too great a workload. I think it really speaks to the engaging nature of the professor, who made the context easily understandable and accessible.
I would recommend this course to another student if they want to gain a more heightened, nuanced understanding of a wide variety of music and truly commit to the study of music as an entity
Yes, interesting and informative. Helpful instructor providing a clear path to success.
